nodes.text: A face recognition system based on Principal Component Analysis and the eigenface approach can provide an efficient, practical solution for recognizing human faces in constrained environments
Eigenface approach represents each training image as a linear combination of eigenvectors (eigenfaces) obtained from the covariance matrix of the training set and reduces dimensionality
Recognition is performed by projecting a test image into the eigenface subspace, computing weights, and classifying by minimum Euclidean distance between weight vectors

Computational optimization: instead of computing eigenvectors of the large covariance matrix C, compute eigenvectors of the M by M matrix L=A^T A to obtain the top M eigenvectors for the eigenface basis

The implemented system was developed in MATLAB and tested on the ETE-07 series RUET student image database (36 images of 18 persons) using image sizes including 200 by 149 pixels and multiple formats (BMP, PNG, JPEG)
Preprocessing steps: center and resize face images, convert each M by N image into an MN by 1 vector, compute mean face, subtract mean to obtain centered vectors
Select only K eigenvectors corresponding to the largest K eigenvalues to form the face space because low-eigenvalue eigenfaces contribute little to characteristic features
Compute feature weights for a face by projecting the mean-subtracted image onto each of the K eigenfaces producing a K-dimensional weight vector
Classification uses Euclidean distance between the test image weight vector and training weight vectors; the class with minimum distance is selected and thresholding distinguishes unknown faces
Experimental tests included cases where test and stored images had the same pose and cases with pose variation; results are shown for both types
The implementation cached initialization outputs (eigenfaces and training projections) to avoid reinitializing and to improve execution time and system performance

Experimental results: the system successfully recognized human faces, performed well under different face orientations, and gave good classification on tested bitmap, PNG, and JPEG images though size variation remains a limitation
Conclusion: The eigenface PCA method is fast, relatively simple, and works well in constrained environments providing a practical face recognition solution
Limitation: The method has limitations with variations in image size and was tested on a small dataset of 36 images from 18 persons, limiting generalizability
Future work proposed: extend to real-time video-based recognition, use a much larger database, handle different image sizes, and compare PCA performance with other face recognition methods
